{{Eastern Slavic name|Magomedovich|Kamalov}} {{use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Gadzhimurat Magomedovich Kamalov | image = Gadzhimurat Kamalov.jpg | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1965|2|11|df=y}} | birth_place = Sogratl, Gunibsky District, Republic of Dagestan, Russia | death_date = {{death date and age|2011|12|15|1965|2|11|df=y}} | death_place = Makhachkala, Republic of Dagestan, Russia | education = | occupation = Publisher, editor and investigative journalist | alias = | title = | family = | spouse = | domestic_partner = | children = | relatives = | nationality = Dagestani / Russian | years_active= 2003–2011 | credits = Founder and publisher of Chernovik (2003–2011), Editor-in-chief of Chernovik (2005–2006) | agent = | website = }}
'''Gadzhimurat Magomedovich Kamalov''', ({{lang-ru|Хаджимурад Магомедович Камалов}}, also spelled '''Gadjimurat''', '''Gadzhimurad''', '''Khadzhimurat''', or '''Khadzhimurad Kamalov'''; 11 February 1965 – 15 December 2011) was a Russian [[investigative journalist]] and the owner of Svoboda Slova (translated as "Freedom of Speech"), the media company that published the newspaper ''[[Chernovik]]''.<ref name=Telegraph>{{cite news|last=Foreign Staff|title=Investigative journalist shot dead in Russian province|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/8961873/Investigative-journalist-shot-dead-in-Russian-province.html|accessdate=16 December 2011|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=16 December 2011}}</ref>
Kamalov was shot dead in an apparent assassination as his name had been put on a hit list for his reporting on Muslim rebel activity in the [[Republic of Dagestan]], and he had been well known for his reporting on corruption.<ref name=Global>{{cite news|last=La|first=Lynn|title=Russian journalist, Khadzhimurad Kamalov, shot dead|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/europe/russia/111216/russian-journalist-khadzhimurad-kamalov-shot-dead|accessdate=16 December 2011|newspaper=Global Post|date=16 December 2011}}</ref> His death is said to have had a chilling effect on other journalists.{{Citation needed|date=December 2011}}
==Personal life== Gadzhimurat Kamalov, an ethnic [[Caucasian Avars|Avar]],<ref name=RFERL>{{cite news|title=Does Kamalov's Death Herald New Power Struggle in Daghestan?|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/kamalov_death_may_herald_new_daghestan_power_struggle/24427076.html|accessdate=20 December 2011|newspaper=Radio Free Europe / Radio Liberty|date=19 December 2011}}</ref> was born in the village of Sogratl, in the [[Gunibsky District]] of Dagestan, [[Russia]].<ref name=bio>{{cite news|title=Kamalov Khadzhimurad Magomedovich|url=http://www.kavkaz-uzel.ru/articles/197741/|accessdate=18 December 2011|newspaper=Kavkaz Uzel (Caucasian Knot)|date=16 December 2011}}</ref> He was married and had one child. His uncle, Ali Kamalov, was the chair of the Union of Journalists in Dagestan at the time his nephew was killed.<ref name=IFEX>{{cite news|title=Campaigns and Advocacy: Meeting highlights common challenges faced by journalists, civil society activists|url=http://www.ifex.org/russia/2011/12/20/shared_experiences/|accessdate=21 December 2011|newspaper=ARTICLE 19/IFEX|date=19 December 2011}}</ref>
He was educated in engineering at the [[Dagestan Polytechnic Institute]] in 1982 and later at the [[Leningrad Technical University]] in 1990.<ref name=bio/>
Kamalov began his journalism career by working at the [[New Business]] (Russian: Новое Дело).<ref name=bio/> After founding a major newspaper in Dagestan, he served as press secretary for President [[Mukhu Aliyev]],<ref name=RFERL/> whose term lasted from 2006 to 2010. Kamalov was also a member of the president's Council of Economic Advisers under President [[Magomedsalam Magomedov]].<ref name=Regnum2>{{cite news|script-title=ru:Президент Дагестана: Убийство Камалова - это большая потеря для всей республики|url=http://www.regnum.ru/news/1480516.html|accessdate=20 December 2011|newspaper=Regnum|date=16 December 2011|language=Russian}}</ref>
==Work== On 19 August 2003,<ref name=Salon>{{cite news|last=Mollayev |first=Arsen |title=Prominent Journalist Gunned Down In Russia's South |url=http://www.salon.com/2011/12/16/prominent_journalist_gunned_down_in_russias_south/ |accessdate=17 December 2011 |newspaper=Salon |date=16 December 2011 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Kamalov founded the newspaper ''Chernovik'' ({{lang-ru|Черновик}}, which translates as "Rough Draft"),<ref name=Guardian1>{{cite news|last=Parfitt|first=Tom|title=Newspaper chief's murder in Dagestan adds to toll of Russian journalists|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/16/russia-journalist-safety?intcmp=239|accessdate=16 December 2011|newspaper=Guardian (U.K.)|date=16 December 2011}}</ref> which was well known for investigating government corruption in Dagestan.<ref name=Telegraph/>
The most controversial article published in ''Chernovik'' was "Terrorist No. 1", which included quotes from [[Rappani Khalilov]], in July 2008, and that led to a legal case between the government and ''Chernovik'' that lasted until May 2011.<ref name=RSF-Report/><ref name=warning>{{cite news|title=Paper receives "warning" from prosecutor's office in Russia's Dagestan|newspaper=Regnum|date=9 July 2008}}</ref> Khalilov was killed on 18 September 2007 before the article was published. He had been sought after as a high-profile terrorist target because of his involvement in the 1999 raid from [[Chechnya]] into Dagestan and a 2002 bombing that killed 40 people.<ref>{{cite news|title=In Brief: Russian Forces Kill Islamist Rebel|newspaper=Moscow News|date=21 September 2007}}</ref><ref name=RGVK-TV>{{cite video|date=21 September 2007|title= Rebel killed in Russia's Dagestan led "extremist group" - TV -- BBC Worldwide Monitoring|format=transcript|medium=TV|language=Russian|publisher=RGVK TV|location=Makhachkala, Republic of Dagestan, Russia|accessdate=18 December 2011}}</ref> The editor of ''Chernovik'' was called to the prosecutor's office and warned before charges were filed.<ref name=warning/>
According to [[Nadira Isayeva]], the editor-in-chief of ''Chernovik'' at the time it published the Khalilov article and during its legal struggles, "Khadzhimurad had many enemies. He wasn't afraid to spell out his motto: 'A newspaper does not need friends.' He was not without an element of the cavalier. He could go off for some meeting with some frostbitten bandits and come back unharmed. He loved investigating corruption. Many of those exposed by his revelations – senior civil servants, police officers and staff at the prosecutor's office – had criminal pasts, and presents. Some were dangerous and not afraid of killing. Often there were confrontations with the heads of Dagestan's municipalities, many of whom are bandits."<ref name=Guardian2>{{cite news|last=Isayeva|first=Nadira|title=Khadzhimurad Kamalov: a death foreseen|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/16/khadzhimurad-kamalov-a-death-foreseen|accessdate=16 December 2011|newspaper=Guardian (U.K.)|date=16 December 2011}}</ref>
Biyakai Magomedov, the current editor of ''Chernovik'', said, "The corrupt structures have been afraid of us. [...] They couldn’t defeat us in courts, because we won practically all the cases."<ref name=Salon/> The main case against ''Chernovik'' had ended in acquittal on 19 May 2011.<ref name=bio/>
At one point, when ''Chernovik'' lost its financial backers, Kamalov took out loans using his flat as collateral, despite the fact that his wife and child lived there. He also would sell off office equipment, until he finally found new backers.<ref name=Guardian2/>
As the owner, Kamalov did not interfere with the editorial content of the newspaper and he encouraged his journalists to report the truth, according to accounts by Mairbek Agayev, a political columnist for ''Chernovik'', and Mahir Pashayev, a business and economics reporter. "It is the only newspaper without any censorship," said Pashayev.<ref name=Regnum3>{{cite news|script-title=ru:Хаджимурад Камалов предоставил своим сотрудникам настоящую свободу, заявляют коллеги (Дагестан)|url=http://www.regnum.ru/news/1480692.html|accessdate=20 December 2011|newspaper=Regnum|date=17 December 2011|language=Russian}}</ref>
==Media source== Besides being behind the news, Gadzhimurat Kamalov was often called on to be a source for media outlets who were looking for an expert to analyze the deteriorating situation in Dagestan.
===Ekho Moskvy radio, Moscow, 8 July 2005=== :[Kamalov]: "Neither the opposition, nor the Republic of Dagestan's official regional authorities, will be able to sort this situation out [... ] I can tell you that the people are increasingly going to the mosques already with the fully conscious understanding that the laws of the [[Russian Federation]] cannot operate in the Republic of Dagestan, but that the alternative traditional laws work. To be more exact, those with a basis in [[Shar'iah]] law work. And so the number of people with such an understanding of legislation and law-enforcement is increasing. And neither the opposition, nor the regional authorities, faced with this fully formed third force are able to handle this."<ref name=EkhoMoskvy1>{{cite video|date=8 July 2005|title= Journalist fears emergence of Islamic enclaves in Russia's Dagestan -- BBC Worldwide Monitoring|format=transcript|medium=radio|language=Russian|publisher=Ekho Moskvy|location=Moscow, Russia|accessdate=17 December 2011}}</ref>
===Kamalov questions security operation=== On 28 June 2008, Kamalov told Ekho Moskvy, Moscow, that the security forces had killed three people who were not militants but one was a university educator whom Kamalov knew. Kamalov said, "A knock on the door [...] is considered a dangerous thing here. Here everybody is afraid of the police. He once told me that if at any time they would come to his place, he would refuse to open the door. It was precisely because he was afraid of an unauthorized search of his flat that [he] must have refused to open the door to them. Thus, they had a justification to storm the flat." The same account was published in print.<ref name=EkhoMoskvy2>{{cite video|date=28 June 2008|title=Russia: Civilian reported killed in Dagestan 'special operation' -- BBC Worldwide Monitoring|format=transcript|medium=radio|language=Russian|publisher=Ekho Moskvy|location=Moscow, Russia|accessdate=17 December 2011}}</ref>
==Activism== On 26 September 2005, Gadzhimurat Kamalov organized an unprecedented protest in [[Makhachkala]] against the action of the Federal Agency for the Press and Mass Communication to stop the printing and distribution of issues of the ''Chernovik''. Fifty journalists and supporters participated in the protest.<ref name=BBC-Monitoring>{{cite news|title=Russia: Protest at pressure on Dagestan's only independent paper|newspaper=Nadezhda Kevorkova -- BBC Monitoring World Media|date= 26 September 2005}}</ref>
On 25 November 2011, Kamalov led a protest of somewhere between 3,000 and 5,700 participants against the unlawful use of force and the disappearance of civilians allegedly by security forces, an issue on which ''Chernovik'' has focused.<ref name=RFERL/><ref name=Guardian3/>
==Death== {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Assassination of Gadzhimurat Kamalov | partof = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = {{Location map | Russia Dagestan#Russia | relief = 1 | width = 220 | float = center | border=infobox | caption = | alt = Makhachkala is in the Republic of Dagestan, Russia, on the Caspian Sea | label = Makhachkala | marksize = 9 | lat_deg = 42| lat_min = 58| lat_sec = | lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 47| lon_min = 29| lon_sec = | lon_dir = E }} | map_size = | location = Makhachkala, Republic Dagestan, Russia | target = | coordinates = | date = 15 December 2011 | time = | timezone = | type = | fatalities = 1 | injuries = | victim = | perps = | perp = | perpetrators= | perpetrator = | susperps = | susperp = | weapons = | numparts = | numpart = | dfens = | dfen = | footage = }}
Kamalov was shot eight times as he was exiting Chernovik's headquarters on Magomed Hajiyev Street in Makhachkala, Dagestan, a Russian province in the north [[Caucasus]] region, around 11:45 p.m., 15 December 2011.<ref name=Telegraph/><ref name=Regnum1>{{cite news|script-title=ru:Глава Дагестана поручил взять под контроль расследование убийства издателя "Черновика"|url=http://www.regnum.ru/news/1480363.html|accessdate=20 December 2011|newspaper=Regnum|date=16 December 2011|language=Russian}}</ref> The gunman was masked, shot 14 rounds in total, and sped away from the scene of the crime in a black [[Lada Priora]].<ref name=vedomosti>{{cite news|script-title=ru:В Махачкале расстреляли основателя независимой газеты "Черновик"|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/newsline/news/2011/12/16/1454753|accessdate=20 December 2011|newspaper=Vedomosti|date=16 December 2011|language=Russian}}</ref> Kamalov had previously received death threats in September 2009 when he was one of eight journalists included in a hit list distributed anonymously in Makhachkala.<ref name=Guardian1/> The list claimed to be seeking revenge for the deaths of police and civilians during Dagestan's unrest.<ref name=Guardian1/> Kamalov may have been included for his sympathetic portrayals of rebel fighters.<ref name=Guardian2/>
Hundreds attended Kamalov's funeral.<ref name=Guardian1/>
==Reactions== Tanya Lokshina, deputy director of [[Human Rights Watch]] in Moscow, said: "Kamalov's death is terrible and it will have a monstrous effect on the free press in Dagestan. He had many enemies because of Chernovik's searching reports on corrupt businesses and the transgressions of the local [[siloviki]] [law enforcement bodies]." Lokshina blamed the murder on the Russian authorities' governing of the region: "Even if there was a personal aspect to his murder then it became possible because of the atmosphere of complete impunity which the Russian authorities have allowed to flourish there."<ref name=Guardian1/>
The New York-based [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] said that the "murder of Gadzhimurat Kamalov [...] is a lethal blow to press freedom", adding that his murder was "a massive loss for independent journalism in the [[North Caucasus]], Russia's most dangerous place for reporters".<ref name=Telegraph/> The CPJ had already awarded its [[CPJ International Press Freedom Awards|press freedom award]] in 2010 to ''Chernovik''{{'s}} former editor Nadira Isayeva,<ref name=Salon/><ref name=CPJ2>[http://www.cpj.org/2011/12/killing-of-chernovik-founder-in-dagestan-must-be-i.php ''Killing of Dagestani journalist must be investigated''], Committee to Protect Journalists, retrieved 16 December 2011</ref> and the newspaper's reputation for modern [[muckraker|muckraker journalism]] was well known outside of the North Caucasus.<ref name=NYT>{{cite news|last=Schwirtz|first=Michael|title=Journalist Is Shot Dead in Russia's North Caucasus Region|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/17/world/europe/journalist-is-shot-dead-in-russias-north-caucasus-region.html?ref=russia|accessdate=16 December 2011|newspaper=New York Times|date=16 December 2011}}</ref>
The [[United Nations]] [[Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights]] and [[UNESCO]] both called for a credible investigation into the Kamalov assassination. [[Irina Bokova]], the director-general of UNESCO, said, "Fear must not be allowed to muzzle media professionals, deny reporters the basic human right of freedom of expression and bar citizens from accessing information."<ref name=UN>{{cite news|title=UN calls on Russian authorities to probe killing of Dagestan journalist|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=40790&Cr=&Cr1=|accessdate=20 December 2011|newspaper=UN News Centre|date=20 December 2011|agency=United Nations}}</ref>
Magomedsalam Magomedov, president of Dagestan, said: "He always came out for unity and peace, and carrying out dialogue [...] This is a big loss not just for journalists, but for the whole republic."<ref name=Regnum2 /><ref name=Guardian3>{{cite news|last=Parfitt|first=Tom and Miriam Elder|title=Russian journalist gunned down in violent republic of Dagestan|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/16/russian-journalist-gunned-down-dagestan|accessdate=16 December 2011|newspaper=Guardian (U.K.)|date=16 December 2011}}</ref> The president's office officially took control over the murder investigation.<ref name=Regnum1/>
Saygidpasha Umakhanov, a prominent mayor in Dagestan, said, "[Gadzhimurat] was indeed an independent and honest journalist. It's impossible to find another like him.... His numerous friends and the healthy forces in society will do everything to find the killer. [But for that] we really need to be united."<ref name=RFERL/>
==Impact== Yulia Latynina, an expert on the Caucasus region, said, "Just as [Anna] [[Politkovskaya]]'s death meant the loss of information about [[Chechnya]], Kamalov's death will mean that to a large extent we will stop to understand what's going on in Dagestan. People will simply be scared to write anything."<ref name=Moscow>{{cite news|last=Associated Press|title=Prominent Journalist Gunned Down in Dagestan|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/prominent-journalist-gunned-down-in-dagestan/450070.html|accessdate=18 December 2011|newspaper=Moscow Times|date=18 December 2011}}</ref>
==Context== According to the BBC, assassination in Dagestan has become routine as the levels of violence in the autonomous Republic of Dagestan have risen.<ref name=BBC-profile>{{cite news|title=Profile: Regions and territories: Dagestan|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/3659904.stm|accessdate=17 December 2011|newspaper=BBC News|date=22 November 2011}}</ref> The republic is seated between the [[Caspian Sea]] and Chechnya. Whereas in Chechnya, rebels have been advocating independence from Russia, in Dagestan the conflict with the rebels is described as more diffuse.<ref name=BBC-Dangerous>{{cite news|last=Ash|first=Lucy|title=Dagestan - the most dangerous place in Europe|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-15824831|accessdate=17 December 2011|newspaper=BBC News|date=23 November 2011}}</ref> Dagestan is a muli-ethnic country with Avars being the largest among them. The majority of citizens practice [[Sufism|Sufi Islam]] but younger people are attracted to the [[Salafi]]st brand of Islam.<ref name=BBC-Dangerous/><ref name=BBC-insurgency>{{cite news|last=Rosenberg|first=Rosenberg|title=Dagestan's deadly Islamic insurgency|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11777853|accessdate=17 December 2011|newspaper=BBC News|date=18 November 2010}}</ref> The mafia is active throughout the country and use violence, kidnapping and murder to intimidate victims.<ref name=BBC-Dangerous/> The security forces in the country are visible and also use violence to achieve their goals.<ref name=BBC-Dangerous/> The problems of Chechnya have spilled over into Dagestan since war broke out there in the early 1990s and the struggle with Dagestan's Muslim rebels has been going on since that time. In the last years, the situation has become more intense.<ref name=BBC>{{cite news|title=Russia shooting: Dagestan journalist Kamalov shot dead|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-16215302|accessdate=17 December 2011|newspaper=BBC News|date=16 December 2011}}</ref> The problems feeding the violence in Dagestan are therefore a diffuse blend of ethnic, religious, generational, criminal, and authoritarian causes.
Dagestan's press is described by both BBC News<ref name=BBC-profile/> and [[Reporters Without Borders]]<ref name=RSF-Report/> as "pluralistic," but the availability of many sources has not lowered tensions. Dunja Mijatovic, who is the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]] Representative on Freedom of the Media, said, "Daghestan and the Northern Caucasus are known to be among the most dangerous places in the world for journalists."<ref name=Reuters>{{cite news|last=Gutterman|first=Steve|title=Newspaper founder killed in Russia's Dagestan|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/12/16/us-russia-journalist-shooting-idUSTRE7BF15W20111216|accessdate=17 December 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=16 December 2011}}</ref> Press freedom organizations, such as the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] (CPJ) and [[Reporters Without Borders]], have called for the immediate investigation of Kamalov's murder. Russia, however, is on the CPJ's list of the top 10 countries with the worst records of impunity in the killing of journalists.<ref name=Telegraph/><ref name=Reuters/> From 2000 until the time of Kamalov's death, Russia has accrued 18 unsolved cases of murders of journalists, according to the CPJ.<ref name="BBC"/> CPJ lists three journalists from Dagestan before Kamalov who have been killed since 2000 in Makhachkala:<ref name=CPJ-Russia>{{cite web|title=53 Journalists Killed in Russia since 1992/Motive Confirmed|url=http://cpj.org/killed/europe/russia/|work=Killed Since 1992|publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists|accessdate=17 December 2011}}</ref>
* [[Malik Akhmedilov]], the daily editor of the ''Hakikat'' (Translated: The Truth), was killed on 11 August 2009. * [[Abdulla Alishayev]], a TV host on TV-Chirkei, was killed on 2 September 2008. * [[Magomedzagid Varisov]], the editor of ''Novoye Delo'', was killed on 28 June 2005.
Other journalists who were killed but were unconfirmed by CPJ:
* [[Gadzhi Abashilov]], the head of Dagestan's state broadcasting company, was killed in Makhachkala on 21 March 2008.<ref name=CPJ-Abashilov>{{cite web|title=Gadzhi Abashilov|url=http://cpj.org/killed/2008/gadzhi-abashilov.php|publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists|accessdate=19 December 2011}}</ref>
Additionally, Reporters Without Borders lists:<ref name=RSF-Magomedov>{{cite web|title=Young journalist gunned down in northern Dagestan|url=http://en.rsf.org/russie-young-journalist-gunned-down-in-10-05-2011,40254.html|publisher=Reporters Without Borders|date=10 May 2011|accessdate=17 December 2011}}</ref>
* [[Yakhya Magomedov]], a journalist working for ''Assalam'' (Russian: Ассалам), was killed in Kokrek, Dagestan on 8 May 2011.
The newspapers in Dagestan with the highest circulations have all experienced the murder of one of their journalists. The top selling news products in Dagestan, include ''Assalam'', which has the highest circulation and is a moderate Muslim bi-weekly; ''Novoye Delo'' and ''Chernovik''.<ref name=RSF-Report>{{cite book|title=Media Enmeshed in Terror, Threats and Corruption|year=2011|publisher=Reporters Without Borders|pages=5|url=http://en.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/mission_report_north_caucasus_rwb_oct._2011-2.pdf|author=Reporters Without Borders|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320235819/http://en.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/mission_report_north_caucasus_rwb_oct._2011-2.pdf|archivedate=20 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Unlike the others, ''Chernovik'' is an independent newspaper.<ref name=Regnum3/> The newspaper targets the civically engaged audience demographic between the ages of 28 to 45, which makes up 80% of its readership.<ref name=ru-dot-com>{{cite news|script-title=ru:В Махачкале убит известный дагестанский журналист Хаджимурад Камалов|url=http://www.newsru.com/russia/16dec2011/kamalov.html|accessdate=20 December 2011|newspaper=News|date=16 December 2011|language=Russian}}</ref> The popularity of the media has a negative side. The media are caught in the middle as they are a visible target in which all the forces facing Dagestan can attack to get at their enemies (p. 9).<ref name=RSF-Report/>

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} '''[[Samuel Johnson]]'s health''' has been a focus of the biographical and critical analysis of his life. His medical history was well documented by Johnson and his friends, and those writings have allowed later critics and doctors to infer diagnoses of conditions that were unknown in Johnson's day. His health and conditions had "damaging effects on Johnson's personal and professional lives"{{Harvnb|Demaria|1994|pp=5–6}} likely causing him to lose opportunities to teach at prominent schools, while leading him "towards the invisible occupation of authorship". ==Medical history== ===Scrofula=== Upon birth, Johnson did not cry and, with doubts surrounding the newborn's health, his aunt claimed "that she would not have picked such a poor creature up in the street".{{Harvnb|Watkins|1960|p=25}} As it was feared that the baby might die, the vicar of St Mary's was summoned to perform a baptism.{{Harvnb|Lane|1975|p=16}} Two godfathers were chosen: Samuel Swynfen, a physician and graduate of Pembroke College, and Richard Wakefield, a lawyer, coroner, and Lichfield town clerk.{{Harvnb|Bate|1977|pp=5–6}} Johnson's health improved and he was placed in the nursing care of Joan Marklew. During this period he contracted what is believed to have been [[scrofula]],{{Harvnb|Lane|1975|pp=16–17}} known at that time as the "King's Evil". [[John Floyer (physician)|Sir John Floyer]], a former physician to [[Charles II of England|Charles II]], recommended that the young Johnson should receive the "[[royal touch]]",{{Harvnb|Lane|1975|p=18}} which he received from [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Queen Anne]] on 30 March 1712 at [[St James's Palace]]. Johnson was given a ribbon in memory of the event, which he claimed to have worn for the rest of his life. However, the ritual was ineffective and an operation was performed that left him with permanent scarring across his face and body.{{Harvnb|Lane|1975|pp=19–20}} ===Eyesight problems=== From early childhood, Johnson suffered from poor eyesight. Especially his left eye was weak. This interfered with his education, yet his handwriting was quite legible until the end of his life. There were somewhat contradictory reports about his eyesight from his contemporaries; he appeared to have been near-sighted. Yet he did not use eyeglasses, which were available at that time.{{cite journal | url = http://archopht.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/full/122/9/1370 | pmid = 15364718 | doi=10.1001/archopht.122.9.1370 | volume=122 | issue=9 | title=Blinking Sam: the ocular afflictions of Dr. Samuel Johnson |date=September 2004 |vauthors=Wilson GA, Ravin JG | journal=Arch. Ophthalmol. | pages=1370–4}} His eyesight became worse with age. Boswell first met him in 1763, when Johnson was 54 years old, and noted that he had inflamed eyes. In letters written in 1773 Johnson wrote,
"My fever has departed but has left me a very severe inflammation in the seeing [right] eye. . . . My eye is yet so dark that I could not read..."
===Asthma and emphysema=== ===Insomnia=== ===Fear of madness=== In 1734, Johnson feared that he was suffering from a disease that would lead to him being deemed mad. He wrote, in Latin, a letter asking Samuel Swynfen, his godfather, about his health.{{Harvnb|Bate|1977|p=117}} Swynfen wrote back "from the symptoms therein described, he could think nothing better of his disorder, than it had a tendency to insanity; and without great care might possibly terminate in the deprivation of his rational faculties."{{Harvnb|Wain|1974|p=63}} This Swynfen's response only caused Johnson to fear becoming insane even more. However, Swynfen soon after showed Johnson's letter to others because of its "extraordinary acuteness, research, and eloquence", and this act was so upsetting to Johnson that he could never forgive Swynfen.{{Harvnb|Bate|1977|p=118}} Boswell claimed that Johnson "felt himself overwhelmed with an horrible melancholia, with perpetual irritation, fretfulness, and impatience; and with a dejection, gloom, and despair, which made existence misery". However, Boswell blamed the common understanding of what was "sane" for Johnson's worries over being insane. Johnson was constantly afraid of losing his sanity, but he kept that anxiety to himself throughout his life. There were, however, occasional outbursts that worried his friends.{{Harvnb|Bate|1977|p=407}} In June 1766, Johnson was on his knees before [[John Delap]], a clergyman, "beseeching God to continue to him the use of his understanding" in a "wild" manner that provoked Johnson's friend, Henry Thrale to "involuntarily [lift] up one hand to shut his mouth".{{Harvnb|Hill|1897|p=423 (Vol. 1)}} The Thrales were afraid for his mental health, and took Johnson into their home in Streatham for a few months, in the hope that might aid his recovery. Thrale's experience is similar to many other accounts; James Anderson reported Adam Smith as telling him: {{quote|I have seen that creature bolt up in the midst of a mixed company; and, without any previous notice, fall upon his knees behind a chair, repeat the Lord's Prayer and then resume his seat at table. He has played this freak over and over, perhaps five or six times in the course of an evening. It is not hypocrisy, but madness.{{Harvnb|Hill|1897|p=423 (Vol. 2)}}}} Although this claim is similar to what the Thrales reported, Boswell wrote: "There is, I am convinced, great exaggeration in this, not probably on Smith's part, who was one of the most truthful of men, but on his reporter's."{{Harvnb|Hill|1897|p=424 (Vol. 2)}} Early on, when Johnson was unable to pay off his debts, he began to work with professional writers and identified his own situation with theirs.{{Harvnb|Pittock|2004|p=159}} During this time, Johnson witnessed [[Christopher Smart]]'s decline into "penury and the madhouse", and feared that he might share the same fate. In joking about Christopher Smart's madness, his writing for the ''Universal Visiter'', and his own contributions, Johnson claimed: "for poor Smart, while he was mad, not then knowing the terms on which he was engaged to write ... I hoped his wits would return to him. Mine returned to me, and I wrote in 'the Universal Visitor' no longer".{{Harvnb|Keymer|1999|p=188}} The truth was that Johnson wrote for the ''Universal Visiter'' as an "act of charity" to the ailing Smart.{{Harvnb|Pittock|2004|p=163}} [[Hester Thrale|Hester Thrale Piozzi]], in her ''British Synonymy'' Book 2, did not joke about Johnson's possible madness, and claimed, in a discussion on Smart's mental state, that Johnson was her "friend who feared an apple should intoxicate him".{{Harvnb|Keymer|1999|p=186}} She made it clear who she was referring to when she wrote in ''Thraliana'' that "I don't believe the King has ever been much worse than poor Dr Johnson was, when he fancied that eating an Apple would make him drunk." To Hester Thrale, what separated Johnson from others who were placed in asylums for madness—like Christopher Smart—was his ability to keep his concerns and emotions to himself. However, Johnson was receiving a treatment of sorts, and it is possible that it involved a set of [[fetters]] and [[padlock]].{{Harvnb|Piozzi|1951|p=415 note 4}} John Wiltshire later determined that these instruments were not symbolic, but actually used in private treatment.{{Harvnb|Wiltshire|1991|pp=43–49}} ===Stroke=== On 17 June 1783, Johnson had a stroke resulting from poor circulation{{Harvnb|Wiltshire|1991|p=51}} and he wrote to his neighbour, Edmund Allen, that he had lost the ability to speak.{{Harvnb|Watkins|1960|p=71}} Two doctors were brought in to aid Johnson; he regained his ability to speak two days later.{{Harvnb|Watkins|1960|pp=71–72}} Johnson believed that his stroke actually helped him, as if it had some sort of cancelling effect in relation to his other health issues: "My disorders are in other respects less than usual, my disease whatever it was seems collected into this one dreadful effect. My Breath is free, the constrictions of the chest are suspended, and my nights pass without oppression".{{Harvnb|Wiltshire|1991|p=36}} ===Gout=== Johnson suffered from what he and his doctors labelled as [[gout]] starting in 1775 when he was 65, and again in 1776, 1779, 1781, and 1783. He told William Boswell, in 1783, that "the Gout has treated me with more severity than any former time, it however never climbed higher than my ankles". Some of Johnson's friends and even his doctor believed that gout would actually help Johnson breathe.{{Harvnb|Wiltshire|1991|pp=35–36}} However, surgery was performed in hope of relieving Johnson's gout.{{Harvnb|Watkins|1960|p=73}} This did not cure the gout, but Johnson tried another path which was to soak his feet in cold water; this only caused Johnson further health issues, but he claimed that it ended his gout problems. The onset of his condition is beyond the probable onset for gout, and the way the gout was limited to Johnson's ankles, along with the confusion between arthritis and gout during Johnson's day, suggests to Pat Rogers that it was really a type of degenerative arthritis.Rogers 1986 pp. 133–144 ===Sarcocele=== In 1782, Johnson was alarmed by a tumour that was diagnosed as a "sarcocele" (testicular tumour). This caused him great pain, and he underwent an apparently successful surgical operation, but the condition recurred.Sir John Hawkins, ''The Life of Samuel Johnson, LL.D.,'' 2nd edition, 1787, London. ==Posthumous diagnosis== The various biographies on Johnson have provided evidence for several [[posthumous diagnosis|posthumous diagnoses]] of Johnson. Before the writings of Lawrence C. McHenry in 1967, many of Johnson's actions and health related aspects were characterised as part of his ongoing depression. It was not until afterwards that the depression became a secondary component of Tourette syndrome, and this diagnosis has become the dominant explanation for many of Johnson's behaviours. ===Depression=== There are many accounts of Johnson suffering from possible bouts of depression or what he himself thought might be "madness". As Walter Jackson Bate puts it, "one of the ironies of literary history is that its most compelling and authoritative symbol of common sense—of the strong, imaginative grasp of concrete reality—should have begun his adult life, at the age of twenty, in a state of such intense anxiety and bewildered despair that, at least from his own point of view, it seemed the onset of actual insanity".{{Harvnb|Bate|1955|p=7}} After leaving Pembroke College, Johnson began to experience "feelings of intense anxiety" along with "feelings of utter hopelessness" and lassitude.{{Harvnb|Bate|1977|p=115}} He told [[John Paradise]], a friend, that he "could stare at the town clock without being able to tell the hour". To overcome these feelings, Johnson tried to constantly involve himself with various activities, but this did not seem to help. Taylor, in reflecting on Johnson's states, said that Johnson "at one time strongly entertained thoughts of Suicide".{{Harvnb|Bate|1977|p=116}}{{Harvnb|Boswell|1969|p=468}} ===Tourette syndrome=== Johnson displayed signs consistent with several diagnoses described in the ''[[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]]'', and it is widely accepted that Johnson had [[Tourette syndrome]] (TS),{{Harvnb|Stern|2005}} a condition unknown during [[History of Tourette syndrome|Johnson's lifetime]]. Johnson [[Societal and cultural aspects of Tourette syndrome#Samuel Johnson|displayed signs of TS]] as described by the writings of Boswell:
... while talking or even musing as he sat in his chair, he commonly held his head to one side towards his right shoulder, and shook it in a tremulous manner, moving his body backwards and forwards, and rubbing his left knee in the same direction, with the palm of his hand. In the intervals of articulating he made various sounds with his mouth; sometimes giving a half whistle, sometimes making his tongue play backwards from the roof of his mouth, as if clucking like a hen, and sometimes protruding it against his upper gums in front, as if pronouncing quickly under his breath, 'Too, too, too.' All this accompanied sometimes with a thoughtful look, but more frequently with a smile. Generally when he had concluded a period, in the course of a dispute, by which time he was a good deal exhausted by violence and vociferation, he used to blow out his breath like a whale.{{Harvnb|Hibbert|1971|p=203}}
There are many similar accounts; in particular, Johnson was said to act in such a manner at the thresholds of doors, and [[Frances Reynolds]] claims that, "with poor Mrs Williams, a blind lady who lived with him, he would quit her hand, or else whirl her about on the steps as he whirled and twisted about to perform his gesticulations".{{Harvnb|Hibbert|1971|p=202}} When asked by Christopher Smart's niece, a young child at the time, why he made such noises and acted in that way, Johnson responded: "From bad habit." [[File:Johnson 1769.jpg|thumb|left|[[Joshua Reynolds|Reynolds']] 1769 portrait depicting Johnson's "odd gesticulations"{{Harvnb|Lane|1975|p=103}}]] He had a number of [[tic]]s and other involuntary movements; the signs described by Boswell and others suggest that Johnson had [[Tourette syndrome]] (TS).{{Harvnb|Pearce|1994|p=396}}{{Harvnb|Murray|1979|p=1610}} In 1994, J. M. S. Pearce analysed—in a ''[[Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine]]'' report—the details provided by Boswell, Hester Thrale, and others, in an attempt to understand Johnson's physical and mental condition. Based on their anecdotal evidence, Pearce compiled a list of movements and tics which Johnson was said to have demonstrated. From that list, he determined it was possible that Johnson was affected by [[History of Tourette syndrome|Tourette syndrome as described]] by [[Georges Albert Édouard Brutus Gilles de la Tourette|Georges Gilles de la Tourette]].{{Harvnb|Pearce|1994|p=398}} Pearce concluded that the "case of Dr Johnson accords well with current criteria for the Tourette syndrome; he also displayed many of the obsessional-compulsive traits and rituals which are associated with this syndrome". Pearce was not alone in diagnosing Johnson as having Tourette syndrome; in 1967 Lawrence C. McHenry Jr{{Harvnb|McHenry|1967|pp=152–168}} was the first to diagnose Johnson with the syndrome but in passing.{{Harvnb|Wiltshire|1991|p=29}} It was not until [[Arthur K. Shapiro]]'s ''Gilles de la Tourette Syndrome'' that the diagnosis was made clear through a comprehensive study, with Shapiro declaring, "Samuel Johnson ... is the most notable example of a successful adaptation to life despite the liability of Tourette syndrome".{{Harvnb|Shapiro|1991|p=361}} [[Thomas John Murray|T. J. Murray]] had come to the same conclusion in a 1979 ''[[British Medical Journal]]'' paper. Murray based his diagnosis on various accounts of Johnson displaying physical tics, "involuntary vocalisations" and "compulsive behaviour".{{Harvnb|Murray|1979|pp=1611–1612}} In a 2007 analysis, Thomas Kammer discusses the "documented evidence" of Johnson's tics, saying that Johnson was "known to have suffered from TS".{{Harvnb|Kammer|2007|p=9}} According to neurologist [[Oliver Sacks]], "the case for Samuel Johnson having the syndrome, though [...] circumstantial, is extremely strong and, to my mind, entirely convincing".{{Harvnb|Sacks|1992|p= 1515}} He continues by generally describing the "enormous spontaneity, antics, and lightning quick wit" that featured prominently in Johnson's life. However, Pearce goes further into Johnson's biography and traces particular moments in Johnson's life which reinforced his diagnosis, concluding:
It is not without interest that periodic boundless mental energy, imaginative outbursts of inventiveness and creativity, are, characteristic of certain Tourette patients. It may be thought that without this illness Dr Johnson's remarkable literary achievements, the great dictionary, his philosophical deliberations and his conversations may never have happened; and Boswell, the author of the greatest of biographies would have been unknown.

''[[MADtv]]''
''[[Drew Carey's Improv-A-Ganza]]''
''[[Whose Line Is It Anyway? (U.S. TV series)|Whose Line Is It Anyway?]]'' }} '''Heather Anne Campbell''' is an [[Americans|American]] writer, comedian, and [[Improvisational theatre|improv]] comedy performer. ==Life and career== Born in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], Campbell began studying [[improvisational comedy]] at [[iO Theater]] at the age of fifteen, under the tutelage of [[Del Close]].{{cite web|url=https://ucbcomedy.com/user/6763|title=Heather Anne Campbell|work=UCB Comedy|date= |accessdate=October 18, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.packtheater.com/performers/heather-anne-campbell/|title=Heather Anne Campbell|work=The Pack Theater|date= |accessdate=October 18, 2018}} Following a four-year stint of performing in [[Northwestern University]]'s ''[[Mee-Ow Show]]'', she relocated to [[Amsterdam]] in 2002 for three years as part of the comedy group [[Boom Chicago]]. In 2005, Campbell moved to [[Los Angeles]] and found work with multiple comedy clubs such as [[The Groundlings]] and the [[Upright Citizens Brigade Theater]]. Campbell currently performs in and writes for ''[[The Midnight Show]]'', a monthly sketch showcase at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater, and is a recurring performer on the CW's [[Whose Line Is It Anyway? (U.S. TV series)|Whose Line Is It Anyway]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2919910/|title=Whose Line Is It Anyway?|website=IMDb.com}}{{better source needed|reason=IMDb not a reliable source|date=October 2018}} Campbell was also a writer on Cartoon Network's ''[[Incredible Crew]]''. From 2013, she began writing for Adult Swim's [[The Eric Andre Show]]. She also currently writes for FOX's [[Animation Domination]],{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2287380/fullcredits#cast|title=Incredible Crew: Series Cast|website=IMDb.com}}{{better source needed|reason=IMDb not a reliable source|date=October 2018}} and is a voice talent behind various short clips on Fox's [[Animation Domination High-Definition]] (ADHD) airing on Saturday nights. She has appeared on Comedy Central's [[@midnight]] four times. Campbell appeared on ''[[MADtv]]'' and was the featured singer in [[Improv Everywhere]]'s Food Court Musical.{{cite web|url=http://improveverywhere.com/2008/03/09/food-court-musical/ |title=Food Court Musical |publisher=Improv Everywhere |date=2008-03-09 |accessdate=2012-02-13}} In 2009, Campbell played a featured character named "Pink" in the [[web series]] ''MegaBot''.{{Cite web|url=http://whedonesque.com/comments/21747|title=Fran Kranz is Blue in Megabot (NSFW)|website=whedonesque.com|date=September 23, 2009|accessdate=April 17, 2016}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8yii8cK2A9o|title=MegaBot Trailer|website=YouTube|date=July 26, 2009|accessdate=April 17, 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.heatherannecampbell.com/blog/megabot-premieres-online|title=MEGABOT PREMIERES ONLINE!|author=Heather Campbell|website=heatherannecampbell.com|date=September 23, 2009|accessdate=April 17, 2016}} In September 2010, Campbell was hired as a [[List of Saturday Night Live writers|writer]] for [[Saturday Night Live (season 36)|Season 36]] of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''.[http://www.thecomicscomic.com/2010/08/meet-two-more-new-writers-for-snls-36th-season-heather-anne-campbell-and-tom-flanigan.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100902045740/http://www.thecomicscomic.com/2010/08/meet-two-more-new-writers-for-snls-36th-season-heather-anne-campbell-and-tom-flanigan.html |date=September 2, 2010 }} In March 2011, Campbell appeared in ''[[Drew Carey's Improv-A-Ganza]]'', a shortform improv show that aired on [[Game Show Network|GSN]]. Campbell has also appeared in commercials for [[Cici's Pizza]], [[Wendy's]], Toyota, and was featured in Activision's "Mapathy" campaign for the video-game Modern Warfare 2.{{Citation needed|date=April 2016}} She has written several viral internet videos for The Midnight Show, including Twilight with Cheeseburgers,{{cite web|url=http://perezhilton.com/2009-04-28-twilight-with-cheeseburgers |title=Twilight - with Cheeseburgers! |publisher=PerezHilton.com |date=2009-04-28 |accessdate=2012-02-13}} Bavatar,{{cite news|author=First Posted: 4/20/10 Updated: 5/25/11 |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/02/18/avatar-babies-gold-video_n_467573.html |title=Avatar Gets Spoofed...With Babies (VIDEO) |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= 2010-02-18|accessdate=2012-02-13}} and "Drive Recklessly", which was nominated for The Comedy Awards on Comedy Central in 2012. Campbell's photography has been selected by [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] as Photo of the Day,{{Cite web|url=http://photography.nationalgeographic.com/photography/photo-of-the-day/arno-river-bridge/|website=nationalgeographic.com|title=Arno River, Florence|date=February 13, 2013|accessdate=April 17, 2016}} and her poster design work was featured as the back cover of [[Adbusters]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2016}} In addition, Campbell is also a video-games journalist, and was editor of [[Dave Halverson]]'s ''[[Play (US magazine)|Play Magazine]]'' as well as Jeff Bond's ''[[Geek Monthly]]'' until their closure in 2010.{{Citation needed|date=April 2016}} Formerly, Campbell was also the Executive Editor of Fusion Publishing's ''Rocket Magazine'', in addition to being a freelance contributor for Edge Online, Action Button, and EGM.{{cite web|url=http://www.egmnow.com/ |title=Video games, Gaming News, Video Game Reviews, Video Game Previews & Game Trailers and Random Geekery |publisher=EGMNOW |date= |accessdate=2012-02-13}}{{not in citation given|date=October 2018}} ==Personal life== Campbell identifies as a [[Libertarian]] and has expressed interest in [[cryptocurrency]] such as [[Bitcoin]]. In October 2018, she [[Coming out|came out]] on [[Instagram]] as part of [[National Coming Out Day]].https://www.instagram.com/p/Bo0AnNzAEn0/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link ==See also== {{portal|Biography}} *[[Whose Line Is It Anyway? (U.S. TV series)#Cast of performers|List of ''Whose Line Is It Anyway?'' performers]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Heather Anne Campbell}} * [http://heatherannecampbell.com/ Official website] * [https://www.instagram.com/heatherannecampbell/ Official Instagram] * {{IMDb name|id=2216111}} {{Whose Line Is It Anyway?}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Campbell, Heather Anne}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American television actresses]] [[Category:American women comedians]] [[Category:American freelance journalists]] [[Category:American libertarians]] [[Category:Actresses from Chicago]] [[Category:Comedians from Illinois]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Upright Citizens Brigade Theater performers]] [[Category:LGBT actresses]] [[Category:LGBT comedians]] [[Category:American women non-fiction writers]]

| box_width = }} '''Hendrik "Hendri" Coetzee''' (c. 1975 – 7 December 2010) was a renowned{{cite web|url=http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/world/noted-outdoorsman-hendrik-coetzee-presumed-dead-after-crocodile-attack_100472289.html|title=Noted Outdoorsman Hendrik Coetzee Presumed Dead After Crocodile Attack|last=Gomez|first=Gina|date=10 December 2010|work=thaindian.com}} South African outdoorsman and author.{{cite web|url=http://www.aolnews.com/world/article/outdoorsman-hendrik-coetzee-presumed-dead-after-congo-crocodile-attack/19753845|title=Kayaker Presumed Dead After Congo Crocodile Attack|last=Gross|first=Jenny|date=9 December 2010|work=aolnews.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101212072926/http://www.aolnews.com/world/article/outdoorsman-hendrik-coetzee-presumed-dead-after-congo-crocodile-attack/19753845|archivedate=12 December 2010|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.spokesman.com/blogs/outdoors/tags/hendrik-coetzee/|title=Northwest kayakers with guide killed by crocodile|last=Rich|date=9 December 2010|work=spokesman.com}} He was killed after being [[crocodile attack|taken by a crocodile]] in December 2010.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1337202/Hendrik-Coetzee-presumed-dead-dragged-craft-crocodile-kayaking-trip-lifetime.html|title=American tourists watch in horror as their Congo River guide is pulled from kayak by crocodile|date=11 December 2010|work=dailymail.co.uk}}{{cite web|url=http://wap.cbsnews.com/site?sid=cbsnews&pid=sections.detail&catId=WORLD&storyId=7134039 |title=Famed Outdoorsman Hendrik Coetzee in Croc Attack |date=9 December 2010 |work=cbsnews.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100316110938/http://wap.cbsnews.com/site?sid=cbsnews |archivedate=16 March 2010 |df=dmy-all }} Coetzee gained prominence in 2004 leading a Nile River source-to-sea expedition, following in the path of [[John Goddard (adventurer)|John Goddard's]] expedition.[[John Goddard (adventurer)|John Goddard]]Goddard, John (1979). Kayaks down the Nile. Brigham Young University Press{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/africa/12/09/kayaker.crocodile/index.html?npt=NP1|title=River guide believed killed by crocodile in Congo|date=10 December 2010|work=cnn.com}}{{cite web|url=http://outside-blog.away.com/blog/2010/12/on-the-death-of-hendri-coetzee.html|title=On the Death of Hendri Coetzee|last=Adventure Lab|date=8 December 2010|work=outside-blog.away.com}} The expedition set off from Lake Victoria in Uganda on 17 January, reaching Khartoum on 25 March{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200403250438.html|title=Nile Expedition Arrives in Khartoum|last=Mutumba|first=Richard|date=25 March 2004|work=allafrica.com}} and the Mediterranean Sea at [[Rosetta]] on 21 May.{{cite news|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/Features/Rafters-complete-Nile-journey-20040521|title=Rafters complete Nile journey|date=21 May 2004|work=news24.com|author=Jasper Mortimer}} The purpose of the trip was to draw attention to the humanitarian situation in the region in partnership with [[CARE (relief agency)|CARE]].{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/Features/South-Africans-join-Nile-team-20040112|title=South Africans join Nile team|date=31 January 2004|work=news24.com}} Following claims that the expedition had not begun from the true source of the Nile, Coetzee's party undertook a further journey from Kagera to Lake Victoria in April 2005, adding 750 km to the 6700 km they completed in 2004.{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/rivers/news/article.cfm?c_id=307&objectid=10123295|title=Rafters epic journey reopens debate on true source of the Nile|date=2 May 2005|work=nzherald.co.nz|accessdate=12 December 2010}} Coetzee was leader of an expedition going from the source of the [[White Nile]] into the Congo at the time of the attack. The trip was the first-of-its-kind kayaking expedition from the [[White Nile]] and [[Congo river]]s into the Congo to explore the [[Ruzizi River|Ruzizi]] and [[Lualaba River]]s. The two other men on the trip, Americans and also experienced kayakers, were documenting unexplored whitewater and development projects in the region.''[[The Economist]]'', "Hendrik Coetzee", 1 January 2010, p. 78. A memorial service for Coetzee was held on 28 January 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.sundayindependent.co.za/killed-after-his-best-day-ever-1.999885|title=Killed after his 'best day ever'|last=Gerretson|first=Bronwyn|date=10 December|work=sundayindependent.co.za}} The documentary short film ''Kadoma'' about Coetzee was released in 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.vaildaily.com/article/20110602/AE/110609956|title='Epics are born'|last=Schnell|first=Caramie|date=2 June 2011|work=vaildaily.com|accessdate=13 October 2011}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://greatwhiteexplorer.blogspot.ca/ the great white explorer]: Personal blog * [http://www.journeyman.tv/57562/documentaries/river-people.html Journeyman Pictures: River People] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120526132536/http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/9/223/434383 Ugandan rafters conquer River Kagera] 14 May 2005 {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Coetzee, Hendrik}} [[Category:1970s births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Explorers of Africa]] [[Category:White South African people]] [[Category:Afrikaner people]] [[Category:South African people of Dutch descent]] [[Category:South African explorers]] [[Category:Deaths due to crocodile attacks]] [[Category:South African non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Canoeing deaths]]

'''Hugh I of Oisy''' (died ''circa'' 1111) was the [[castellan]] of the town of [[Cambrai]] and a famous rebel against the authority of the [[Bishop of Cambrai|bishops of the city]].<ref name=Resnick>I. M. Resnick, "Odo of Cambrai and the Investiture Crisis in the Early Twelfth Century", ''Viator'' '''28''' (1997), 85–87.</ref> Hugh's family was of seigneurial rank, originating in [[Oisy, Nord|Oisy]] and [[Inchy]], and had provided most of the castellans of Cambrai during the eleventh and twelfth centuries.<ref name=Resnick/>
Before 1076, Hugh rebelled against the bishop [[Lietbert]] and was excommunicated. The bishop refused to lift the ban "unless [Hugh] first consents to renounce with his own hands—''werpire'', to use the common expression—every fief which he holds in the city of Cambrai."<ref name=Ganshof>[[F. L. Ganshof]], ''Feudalism'', trans. [[Philip Grierson|P. Grierson]] (New York: Harper Torchbook, 1961), 128: ''nisi prius dimissionem manu propria, quod et vulgo werpire dicitur, faceret ex omni beneficio quod infra ambitum Cameracae civitatis habebat''. The source is the ''Gesta Lietberti episcopi Cameracensis'' ("The Deeds of Bishop Lietbert of Cambrai"), written within a quarter-century of the bishop's death.</ref> The ceremony of ''werpitio'' (in French ''déguerpissement'') generally involved handing over a symbol of the fief to the one from whom it had been received.<ref name=Ganshof/>
Hugh continued to encroach on the authority of the bishop within the city during the episcopate of [[Gerard II of Cambrai|Gerard II]]. Since both the French king, [[Philip I of France|Philip I]], and the dowager countess of Hainaut, [[Richilde, Countess of Hainaut|Richilda]], were opposed to increased imperial influence—represented by the bishop of Cambrai—in the [[county of Flanders]], they supported Hugh in his rebellion. With the help of Richilda's rival, Count [[Robert I of Flanders]], the bishop succeeded in exiling Hugh to England between about 1086 and 1090.<ref name=Resnick/>

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} [[Image:Jan Salter at KAT Centre.jpg|right|300px]]
'''Jan Salter MBE''' was the founder of the [[Kathmandu Animal Treatment Centre]] (KAT Centre), a charity organisation that works to create a healthy, sustainable [[Free-ranging urban dog|street dog]] population and eliminate [[rabies]] in [[Kathmandu]], Nepal. She was also an artist<ref> {{cite book | last1 = Wilson-Howarth | first1 = Jane | title = A Glimpse of Eternal Snows: A Family's Journey of Love and Loss in Nepal | publisher = Murdoch Books | year = 2007 | isbn = 978-1921259265}}</ref> who is widely acclaimed for her portraits of people of Nepal.
==Early life== Salter was born in Southampton, England in 1936. During her younger years, she travelled extensively throughout the world, often finding employment as a hairdresser in the countries she visited. This profession gave her the opportunity to earn income to support her travels.<ref>[http://www.katcentre.org.np/news/articles/2011-04_VOW_JanIntervew.doc VOW, Voice of Women magazine], April 2011. Retrieved on 2 April 2012</ref>
Ms. Salter first visited the Himalayan country of [[Nepal]] in 1967 as a tourist. She was hired as a hairdresser in [[Boris Lisanevich]]'s Royal Hotel, one of the first international hotels in the country. She continued to travel worldwide but no other country interested her like Nepal did. In 1975, she returned to [[Kathmandu]], the capital of Nepal, where she lived until 2016.<ref>[http://www.ecs.com.np/feature_detail.php?f_id=260 ECS Magazine], March 2004. Retrieved on 2 April 2012</ref>
At that time, Salter began to create pencil drawings of Nepali people. Although she had no formal training as an artist, her talent became apparent as she compiled a series of more than 100 drawings, and she later expanded into even more oil paintings as well. Salter trekked extensively throughout Nepal, often with her adopted Nepali son Premlal, to produce portraits of the diverse ethnic groups who inhabit different regions of the country. She has enjoyed a successful career as an artist with many exhibitions of her work, and is still widely respected in Nepal and abroad for her representations of the country's many ethnicities.<ref>[http://www.katcentre.org.np/news/articles/2011-04_VOW_JanIntervew.doc VOW, Voice of Women magazine], April 2011. Retrieved on 2 April 2012</ref> Over the years she has helped and befriended many people including [[Jane Wilson-Howarth]] and features in her travel memoir.<ref>{{Cite book| author=Jane Wilson-Howarth| title=A Glimpse of Eternal Snows: a journey of love and loss in the Himalayas | publisher=Bradt Travel Guides, UK | year=2012| pages = 390 | ISBN= 978-1-84162-435-8}}</ref>
==Faces of Nepal== Salter collaborated with the scholar and author Dr. Harka Gurung on a book entitled "Faces of Nepal." The book is a unique ethnographic study of the various ethnic groups of Nepal which combines Gurung's writings about each ethnicity with Salter's drawings and paintings of members of the groups. The book was published in 1996 and received much critical acclaim.<ref>[http://www.nepalitimes.com.np/issue/2003/07/25/BookWorm/10015 Nepali Times], 25 July 2003. Retrieved on 2 April 2012</ref>
In 1997 Salter was decorated with the "Gorkha Dakshin Bahu" award by the then Nepali king, [[Birendra of Nepal|Birendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev]]. She has worked with the organisation [[Maiti Nepal]], which rescues Nepali girls who were trafficked and sold into prostitution. Salter produced a series of paintings entitled "All Our Daughters" of girls who had been rescued by Maiti Nepal.
==Kathmandu Animal Treatment Centre== Salter had long been disturbed by the suffering of the tens of thousands of street dogs in Kathmandu. Many are afflicted with malnutrition, injuries from collisions with vehicles, and infectious diseases. The government poisoned more than 10,000 street dogs every year with strychnine to attempt to reduce their population. While travelling in India in 2003, Ms. Salter visited an organisation called "Help in Suffering" in Jaipur that used spay/neuter surgeries to reduce the street dog population, an approach that was in its infancy in the developing world. Salter recognised that this can be applied on a large scale in Kathmandu and was immediately inspired to take action. At age 68, she stepped back from her career as an artist to devote her time to animal welfare.
Ms. Salter committed her life's financial savings to building and starting the [[Kathmandu Animal Treatment Centre]] (KAT Centre), the first organisation in Nepal working to improve the dog population. The KAT Centre was registered with the government of Nepal as a charity organisation in 2003 and opened on 9 May 2004. It continues to be the largest companion animal welfare organisation in Nepal.<ref>[http://www.katcentre.org.np/news/articles/2011-04_VOW_JanIntervew.doc VOW, Voice of Women magazine], April 2011. Retrieved on 2 April 2012</ref>
The [[KAT Centre]]'s goals are to humanely produce a healthy, stable street dog population and to eliminate rabies in Kathmandu. The core program engenders a sustainable reduction in the canine population through spay/neuter surgeries. As KAT's staff collects every female dog they can in an area to sterilise them and vaccinate them for rabies, they also provide all needed veterinary treatment to street animals in the same area.
Salter knew that to effect an enduring impact, she must transform people's attitudes about the dogs in their city. Therefore, the KAT Centre's animal care is complemented by an education program. KAT teaches children and adults about compassion for animals, street dog welfare, responsible pet ownership, and rabies awareness.<ref>[http://www.ecs.com.np/feature_detail.php?f_id=260 ECS Magazine], March 2004. Retrieved on 2 April 2012</ref>
Salter's approach has produced a visible transformation in the city of Kathmandu, in the number of stray dogs, their health, and people's attitudes towards them. Ms. Salter continues to lead the Kathmandu Animal Treatment Centre. She was the driving force behind the organisation's long-term planning, guiding it towards its goals of creating a healthy, stable dog population and eliminating rabies in Kathmandu. As the public persona of the KAT Centre, Ms. Salter conducted much of the organisation's fundraising and donor relations.<ref>[http://www.katcentre.org.np/news/articles/2011-04_VOW_JanIntervew.doc VOW, Voice of Women magazine], April 2011. Retrieved on 2 April 2012</ref>
In 2010 Salter received the prestigious "Extraordinary Commitment and Achievement award" presented by [[Humane Society International]], and in the UK New Years Honours List for 2013 she received an MBE from Queen Elizabeth II for services to animal welfare in Nepal. <ref>http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/about-us/what-we-do/protocol/honours/dso-list#MBE</ref>
Jan passed away in Lyme Regis on April 29th 2018.

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Refimprove|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox Prime Minister |name=Jean-Jacques-Régis de Cambacérès |image=Maurin - Cambaceres.png |order=[[French Consulate|Second Consul of France]] |alongside =[[Napoléon Bonaparte]] and [[Charles-François Lebrun, duc de Plaisance]] |term_start =12 December 1799 |term_end =18 May 1804 |predecessor =[[Emmanuel Joseph Sieyès]] |successor = Republic abolished |birth_date =18 October 1753 |birth_place =[[Montpellier]] |death_date ={{death date and age|1824|3|8|1753|10|18|df=y|}} |death_place =[[Paris]] |party= }} '''Jean-Jacques-Régis de Cambacérès, duc de Parme''' (18 October 1753{{snd}}8 March 1824), was a French nobleman, lawyer and statesman during the [[French Revolution]] and the [[First French Empire|First Empire]]. He is best remembered as one of the authors of the [[Napoleonic Code]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Jean-Jacques-Regis-de-Cambaceres-duc-de-Parme|title=Jean-Jacques-Regis de Cambaceres, duke de Parme {{!}} French statesman|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2017-08-26|language=en}}{{cite EB1911|ref=harv |wstitle=Cambacérès, Jean Jacques Régis de |volume=5 |pages=80-81}} which still forms the basis of French civil law and French-inspired civil law in many countries. == Early life == Cambacérès was born in [[Montpellier]], into a poor family of the legal [[French nobility|nobility]].{{Cite book |title=The Court and Camp of Bonaparte |author=Harper |publisher=Harper and Brothers |year=1835 |location=New York |pages=132}} (His brother, [[Étienne Hubert de Cambacérès]], later became a cardinal.) In 1774, he graduated in law from the college d'Aix and succeeded his father (who later became mayor of Montepellier) as Councillor in the court of accounts and finances in [[Toulouse]].{{Cite book|title=Historical Dictionary of France: 1799–1815|last=Connelly|first=Owen|publisher=Greenwood|year=1985|isbn=9780313213212|location=Westport, CT|page=|pages=94–95}}{{cite book |title=A Dictionary of Napoleon and His Times |date=1920 |publisher=University of Michigan Library |page=94 |last1=Richardson |first1=Hubert}} He was a supporter of the [[French Revolution]] of 1789, and was elected as an extra deputy to represent the nobility of Montpellier (in case the government doubled the nobility's delegation) at the meeting of the [[Estates-General of 1789|Estates-General]] at [[Versailles, Yvelines|Versailles]]. However, since the delegation was not increased, he never took his seat. In 1792, he represented the [[departments of France|department]] of [[Hérault]] at the [[National Convention]] which assembled and proclaimed the [[First French Republic]] in September 1792. == National Convention == In revolutionary terms, Cambacérès was a moderate republican and sat left of center during the National Convention.{{Cite book|title=Napoleon and His Collaborators|last=Woloch|first=Isser|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company|year=2002|isbn=978-0-393-32341-2|location=|page=|pages=120–155}} During the trial of [[Louis XVI of France|Louis XVI]] he protested that the Convention did not have the power to sit as a court and demanded that the king should have due facilities for his defence. Nevertheless, when the trial proceeded, Cambacérès voted with the majority that declared Louis to be guilty, but recommended that the penalty should be postponed until it could be ratified by a legislative body. This would later save him from being executed for regicide. During the Convention, many of his decisions (like the latter) were well thought out and calculated. Cambacérès made sure that he never committed himself to a certain faction.{{Cite book|title=Napoleon Bonaparte and the Legacy of the French Revolution|last=Lyons|first=Martyn|publisher=St. Martin's Press|year=1994|isbn=|location=|pages=36, 66}} His legal expertise made him useful to all parties; he was a friend to all and an enemy to none. However, due to this, his fellow representatives at the convention did criticize him for sometimes fluctuating on some positions. == Rise under Napoleon == Cambacérès was a member of the Committee of General Defence from 1793 until the end of 1794, and later became a member of its infamous successor, the [[Committee of Public Safety]] after the fall of Robespierre. In the meantime he worked on much of the legislation of the revolutionary period. During 1795, he was employed as a diplomat and negotiated peace with Spain, the [[Grand Duchy of Tuscany]], the [[Kingdom of Prussia]] and the [[Batavian Republic]]. His remarkable debating skills gave him a spot as a councilor of the [[Council of Five Hundred|Five Hundred]] from 1795-1799'''. Cambacérès was considered too conservative to be one of the five Directors who took power in the coup of 1795 and, finding himself in opposition to the [[French Directory|Executive Directory]], he retired from politics. In 1799, however, as the Revolution entered a more moderate phase, he became Minister of Justice. He supported the coup of [[18 Brumaire]] (in November 1799) that brought [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon Bonaparte]] to power as [[First Consul]], a new regime designed to establish a stable constitutional republic. == The Napoleonic Code == [[File:3consuls.jpg|thumb|A portrait of the three Consuls, from left to right: Jean Jacques Régis de Cambacérès, [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon Bonaparte]] and [[Charles-François Lebrun, duc de Plaisance|Charles-François Lebrun]].]] In December 1799, Cambacérès was appointed [[Second Consul]] under Bonaparte. He owed this appointment to his vast legal knowledge and his reputation as a moderate [[republicanism|republican]]. His most important work during this period, and arguably during his entire political career, was the drawing up of a new Civil Law Code (later called the [[Napoleonic Code]]; France's first modern legal code).{{Cite book|title=Napoleon Bonaparte; An Intimate Biography|last=Cronin|first=Vincent|publisher=|year=1972|isbn=|location=|page=|pages=176, 193, 283}} The Code was promulgated by Bonaparte (as [[Napoleon I of France|Emperor Napoleon]]) in 1804. In the end, the Napoleonic Code was the work of Cambacérès and a commission of four lawyers. The Code was a revised form of [[Roman law]], with some modifications drawn from the laws of the [[Franks]] still current in northern France (''Coutume de Paris''). The Code was later extended by Napoleon's conquests to [[Poland]], [[Italy]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Belgium]], western Germany and Spain, and indirectly to the Spanish colonies in [[Latin America]]. Cambacérès' work has thus been enormously influential in European and American legal history. Versions of the Code are still in force in [[Quebec]] and [[Louisiana]]. The Napoleonic Code dealt with Civil Law; other codes ensued for Penal Law, [[criminal procedure]], and civil procedure. == Life with Napoleon (1804–1815) == Cambacérès disapproved of Bonaparte's accumulation of power into his own hands (culminating in the proclamation of the [[First French Empire]] on 18 May 1804) but retained high office under Napoleon: [[Grand Dignitaries of the French Empire|Arch-Chancellor of the Empire]] and [[List of Presidents of the French Senate|President of the House of Peers]] from 2 June, to 7 July 1815. He also became a prince of the Empire and in 1808 was made [[Duke of Parma#Honorary Dukes of Parma (1808–1814)|Duke of Parma]] (French: ''duc de Parme''). His duchy was one of the twenty created as a ''[[duché grand-fief]]'' (among 2200 noble titles created by Napoleon)—a rare hereditary honor, extinguished upon Cambacérès' death in 1824. He was essentially second in command of France during the Napoleonic era. Under Napoleon, he was a force for moderation and reason, opposing adventures such as the Spanish affairs in 1808 and the [[Napoleon's invasion of Russia|invasion of Russia]] in 1812. Nevertheless, Cambacérès was extremely trusted by Napoleon and was constantly consulted for advice; Cambacérès even sat as Council of State when Bonaparte was involved in other affairs. As Napoleon became increasingly obsessed with military affairs, Cambacérès became the ''de facto'' domestic head of government of France, a position which inevitably made him increasingly unpopular as France's economic situation grew worse. As more and more of Napoleon's ministers proved themselves untrustworthy, Cambacérès' power continued to grow. His taste for high living also attracted hostile comments. Nevertheless, he was given credit for the justice and moderation of his government, although the enforcement of conscription was increasingly resented towards the end of the [[Napoleonic Wars]]. When the Empire fell in 1814, Cambacérès retired to private life but was later called upon during Napoléon's brief return to power in 1815. During the [[Hundred Days]], the short period of time when Napoleon returned from exile, Cambacérès served as the minister of justice.{{Cite book|title=Gouvernements, ministères et constitutions de la France depuis cent ans|last=Muel|first=Leon|publisher=Marchal et Billard|year=1891|isbn=978-1249015024|location=|pages=100}} After the [[Bourbon Restoration|restoration of the monarchy]], he was in danger of arrest for his revolutionary activities, and he was exiled from France in 1816. The fact that he had opposed the execution of Louis XVI counted in his favor, and in May 1818 his civil rights as a citizen of France were restored. From 1815 and on, Cambacérès used the title of Duke of Cambacérès (on the fall of the Empire, the Duchy of Parma passed to former Empress Marie Louise). He was a member of the [[Académie française]] and lived quietly in Paris until his death in 1824. == Private life == The common belief that Cambacérès is responsible for decriminalizing homosexuality in France is in error. Before the French Revolution, [[sodomy]] had been a capital crime under royal legislation. The penalty was burning at the stake. Very few men, however, were ever actually prosecuted and executed for consensual sodomy (no more than five in the entire eighteenth century). Sodomites arrested by the police were more usually released with a warning or held in prison for, at most, a few weeks or months. The [[National Constituent Assembly (France)|National Constituent Assembly]] revised French criminal law in 1791 and got rid of a variety of offenses inspired by religion, including [[blasphemy]]. Sodomy was not specifically mentioned but was covered under the umbrella of 'religious crimes'. Since there was no public debate, its motives remain unknown (a similar state of affairs occurred during the early years of the [[Russian Revolution of 1917|Russian Revolution]]).{{cite book |first=Michael |last=Sibalis |chapter=The Regulation of Male Homosexuality in Revolutionary and Napoleonic France, 1789–1815 |title=Homosexuality in Modern France |editor-first=Jeffrey |editor-last=Merrick |editor2-first=Bryant T. |editor2-last=Ragan |location=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=1996 |pages=80–101}} Cambacérès was a homosexual, his sexual orientation was well-known, and he does not seem to have made any effort to conceal it. He remained unmarried, and kept to the company of other bachelors. Napoleon is recorded as making a number of jokes on the subject'''.{{cite book |first=Jean-Louis |last=Bory |title=Les cinq girouettes ou servitudes & souplesse de son Altesse Sérénissime le Prince Archichancelier de l'Empire Jean-Jacques Régis de Cambacérès duc de Parme |location=Paris |publisher=[[Ramsay (publishing house)|Ramsay]] |year=1979 |page={{page needed|date=April 2017}} }} '''Upon hearing that Cambacérès had recruited a woman for a mission, Napoleon responded with, "my compliments, so you have come closer to women?"'''.'''{{Cite book|title=Bonaparte: 1759-1802|last=Gueniffey|first=Patrice|publisher=Gillimard|year=2016|isbn=|location=Paris|page=603|pages=}} [[Robert Badinter]] once mentioned in a speech to the [[French National Assembly]], during debates on reforming the homosexual [[age of consent]], that Cambacérès was known in the gardens of the [[Palais-Royal]] as "Tante Urlurette".{{Cite book|title=Who's who in Gay and Lesbian History|last=Aldrich|first=Robert|publisher=Routledge|year=2000|isbn=|location=|page=95|pages=}}{{cite web |url=http://archives.assemblee-nationale.fr/7/cri/1981-1982-ordinaire1/153.pdf |title=Proceedings of the National Assembly, 2nd sitting of 20 December 1981 |p=5371}} In fact, however, Cambacérès was not responsible for ending the legal prosecution of homosexuals. He did play a key role in drafting the Code Napoléon, but this was a civil law code. He had nothing to do with the Penal Code of 1810, which covered sexual crimes. The authors of the Penal Code of 1810 had the option of reintroducing a law against male homosexuality (as was eventually done in the [[Soviet Union]]), but there is no evidence that they even considered doing so. This had nothing to do with the influence of Cambacérès, as recent research has shown. However, Napoleonic officials could and did repress public expressions of homosexuality using other laws, such as "offenses against public decency". Nevertheless, despite police surveillance and harassment, the Revolutionary and Napoleonic era was a time of relative freedom for homosexuals and opened the modern era of legal toleration for homosexuality in Europe. Napoleonic conquests imposed the principles of Napoleon's Penal Code (including the decriminalization of homosexuality) on many other parts of Europe, including Belgium, the Netherlands, the Rhineland, and Italy. Other states freely followed the French example, including [[Bavaria]] in 1813 and Spain in 1822.{{cite book|first=Michael |last=Sibali |chapter=The Age of Enlightenment and Revolution |editor-first=Robert |editor-last=Aldrich |title=Gay Life and Culture: A World History |location=London |publisher=Thames & Hudson |year=2006 |pages=117–119}} Cambacérès' colleagues also didn't fail to poke fun at his gluttony. When he met with the Council while Napoleon was away, everyone knew that the meeting would be over before lunch. He was known for having the best dinners in France and for his extravagant lifestyle. According to him, "a country is governed by good dinner parties". His estate was worth around 7.3 million francs (around €50 million in 2015 euros) upon his death in 1824. His body now lies in the cemetery of [[Père Lachaise Cemetery|Père Lachaise]] where he was buried with military honors.{{Cite book|title=A Dictionary of Napoleon and His Times|last=Richardson|first=Hubert|publisher=London Cassell|year=1920|isbn=|location=|page=95|pages=}} == Freemasonry == Cambaceres was admitted to the lodge of "Les Amis Fidèles" in Montpellier in 1775. During Napoleon's reign, he was charged by the Emperor to monitor [[Freemasonry]] in France. From 1805 to 1815, he was the assistant of [[Joseph Bonaparte]], Grand Master of [[Grand Orient de France]], and managed the post-revolutionary rebirth of French freemasonry. During his term, more than 1200 lodges were created.{{cite journal |title=La Franc-maçonnerie sous l'Emprire : un age d'or ? |journal=La Franc maçonnerie et l'Etat napoleonien |page=141 |editor-first=Eric |editor-last=Saunier |publisher=Dervy |year=2007 |language=fr}}{{cite book |title=Histoire de la franc-maçonnerie en France |page=231 |first=Jean André |last=Faucher |first2=Achille |last2=Ricker |language=fr}} {{full citation needed |date=April 2017}}{{cite book |title=Cambacérès: Le Premier surveillant de la franc-maçonnerie impériale |first=Pierre-François |last=Pinaud |publisher=Editions maçonniques de France |year=1999 |page={{page needed|date=April 2017}}|language=fr}}{{cite book |title=Cambacérès : Unificateur de la franc-maçonnerie sous le Premier Empire |first=Jean-Paul |last=Delbert |publisher=Grands caractères |year=2005 |page={{page needed|date=April 2017}} }} == References == {{reflist}} == External links== {{Commons category|Jean-Jacques-Régis de Cambacérès}} * {{fr icon}} [http://www.heraldique-europeenne.org/Regions/France/Cambaceres.htm The House of Cambacérès] * {{fr icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20031220044935/http://www.conseil-etat.fr/ce/histoi/index_hp_gf01.shtml French Council of State website on Cambacérès] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20031203080946/http://www.history-magazine.com/codenap.html The Code Napoléon] {{S-start}} {{S-off}} {{Succession box | title= Head of State of France
